Conducting innovative clinical trials is crucial for Abu Dhabi healthcare sector for several reasons: 1. Advancement in Medical Knowledge: Innovative trials help in discovering new treatments, understanding disease mechanisms, and refining existing therapies. They push the boundaries of medical science and contribute to the body of sustainable knowledge. 2. Improved Patient Outcomes: These innovations in clinical trials will lead to the development of more effective and safer treatments, offering better outcomes and improved quality of life for patients. Innovations such as personalized precision medicine can tailor treatments to individual genetic profiles unique to Abu Dhabi patient populations. 3. Efficiency and Speed: Innovative approaches, such as adaptive trial designs and use of real-world data, can streamline the clinical trial process, making it faster and more cost-effective. This allows promising treatments to reach patients sooner. 4. Addressing Unmet Needs: Many diseases, particularly rare or complex conditions, lack effective treatments. Innovative trials can focus on these areas, providing hope and potential solutions for patients who have limited options. 5. Regulatory Adaptation: As medical science advances, regulatory frameworks need to co-evolve. Innovative clinical trials can help regulators understand and adapt to new methodologies, ensuring that policies keep pace with scientific progress. 6. Patient Engagement: Incorporating patient-centric approaches and utilizing technology (like wearable devices and telemedicine) in innovative trials can enhance patient participation and adherence, leading to more robust data and better trial outcomes. 7. Economic Benefits: Efficient and successful clinical trials can reduce healthcare costs by providing more effective treatments and potentially curing diseases. Additionally, successful innovations can stimulate economic growth through the development of new medical products and technologies. We commend you for incorporating innovative clinical trials here in our own backyard, which are deemed essential for the continuous improvement of healthcare, ensuring that new and better treatments are developed and home-made available to those in need.

üåç **Doctys Tele-Pathology and Tele-Radiology: Bridging Borders with Remote Expertise** üß¨ Tele-pathology is reshaping how medical expertise is shared globally. This cutting-edge approach allows pathologists to collaborate remotely, ensuring precise diagnoses regardless of geographic barriers. Our partners in Saudi Arabia are utilizing the Doctys platform to analyze pathology images from Yemen, facilitating seamless cross-border medical consultations. Here's how tele-pathology requests flow between countries: - **Case Preparation**: Medical professionals digitally capture pathology slides for accurate and private diagnosis. - **Secure Transmission**: Images are securely uploaded to a HIPAA-compliant platform, safeguarding sensitive data during transit. - **Remote Review**: Pathologists from different countries access and evaluate images using advanced tools. - **Reporting and Feedback**: A comprehensive report is shared with the medical team, ensuring seamless patient care integration. Tele-pathology not only boosts diagnostic precision but also extends specialized expertise to underserved areas, advancing global patient outcomes. As technology progresses, tele-pathology's potential to transform healthcare grows, bridging healthcare gaps and fostering international collaboration in combating diseases. #TelePathology #MedicalInnovation #GlobalHealth #HealthcareCollaboration #DigitalHealth

As co-course director with the esteemed Dr. Anas Hamad, PhD, MSc, DMS, BSc, RPh Director of Pharmacy Department NCCCR & Head of Medication Safety & Quality Center #HMC. Delighted to share med safety pearls from our successful kickoff webinar "Introduction to #Medication Safety" of new series "Optimizing #MedicationSafety in #PrimaryCare & #Outpatient Settings" Expressing gratitude to Dr. Anas for his insight, expertise & ongoing support & great presentation which illustrated why medication safety is crucial. 4 pearls deeply resonated: 1) The interesting exploration of the historical context from the dualities of Apollo as both "God of Physics & sender of disease" & Pharmakos which means "remedy & poison" to the timeless Hippocratic principle of "first do no harm," highlighying the complexity of medication safety 2) Medications are the most common intervention in healthcare - we all have or will use medication 3) The staggering prevalence & consequences of medical errors - 3rd leading cause of death in the US, almost 2 million GP prescriptions contained errors & approx 712 deaths from avoidable adverse drug reactions. 4) collaboration (instead of blame) & collegiality are key to prevent error & harm! An honor to welcome Dr Reham H. Negmeldin, Assistant Executive Director Quality HHQI-HMC who delivered an interesting & thought provoking presentation on medication error origins starting with the poignant reminder that " to Err is human" and then expertly describing how faulty systems, processes, conditions, as depicted in the "Swiss Cheese Model," are usually to blame for most workplace errors incl approx 250,000 annual ADR deaths! Her question "why are managers & colleagues quick to blame people instead of addressing latent conditions that lead to mistakes " elicited interesting comments! Concluded by emphasizing the importance of recognizing & applying effective error reduction principles, e.g sociotechnical systems, simplifying tasks, standardization, ‚ÄúTeach-back‚Äù, PDSA, capturing & mitigating errors before they cause harm. Great pleasure to welcome Ms Ayat Kadhi Lecturer, UDST & PhD Candidate who highlighted the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration in reducing communication breakdown & improving patient care in her impactful presentation. She recommended communication protocols (SBAR), technology, CPD, monitoring & feedback in enhancing interdisciplinary collaboration & reducing gaps in patient care. Very appreciative of the engaged attendees & my dedicated CPD Weill Cornell Medicine-Qatar colleagues. Don't miss Session 2 #Rootcauses; May 20th 2024. Click https://lnkd.in/degXqXky to register!
